item.description:
TAKE A FEW MINUTES AND REVIEW ALL THE TRIP DETAILS BELOW!  Email me directly (jmmoran@nycap.rr.com) with any questions!  - Julie.

Difficulty:

1.  The NEHH Elephant Mountain:  About just under two miles, about 1,142 Feet Elevation Change;  this is about a two-hour hike.  

2.  B-52 Crash-Site Elephant Mountain:  About two miles, roughly a two mile hike.

 

Car Spot Meetup Time,  Crossroads Diner in Bethel: 8 a.m.

Trailhead Start Time (NEHH Elephant Mountain): About 9:30 a.m.Trailhead Start Time (NEHH Elephant Mountain): About 9:30 a.m.


LINK TO GOOGLE MAPS (CLICK HERE) -- Estimated Trailhead Directions, Distances (link) from the meetup location to the end of the logging road route below the NEHH Elephant Mountain summit; then to the drive to the trailhead for B-52 Crash Site Elephant Mountain.

 

ESSENTIALS TO BRING: Flash light / head lamp, food / snacks / water, first aid items, bug spray, sun screen, cell phone, camera.


EVENT ORGANIZER: 

Julie Moran Contact me here: jmmoran {{ AT }} nycap.rr.com, Mobile 518-281-5882 (PLEASE, NO PHONE CALLS UNTIL THE WEEKEND OF THE EVENT). You can send text messages to me as well.


NARRATIVE AND UPDATES (09-07-2011 7:30 pm):  

Sorry for the late notice on this hike ... With my move to Vermont, starting a new job in getting in home ready, things have been a little crazy here!

I'm having fun picking off the last few remaining new England Hundred Highest peaks along with my new friend Ed.  In the process of researching Elephant Mountain, I was surprised to learn that there are two Elephant Mountains in Maine.  One of these peaks is on the NEHH list, and the more northern one this site of a dramatic and poignant crash in 1963 of a B-52 Stratofortress aircraft, on a training mission as part of the Cold War geopolitical strategy between the US and USSR.  The links below tell the very fascinating, yet tragic, story of what happened to this gigantic aircraft that crashed into a remote mountain in the deep 1963 Maine winter.  Only two of the eight-member crew survived.

My plan is that we will travel from the lower Franconia Notch / Lincoln / Woodstock NH area and rendezvous in Bethel Maine with anyone wishing to join us to bushwhack the relatively easy NEHH Elephant Mountain.  Then, given this is the 10th anniversary of 9/11, I thought it would be appropriate to visit this other Elephant Mountain, and pay respects servicemen and literally fell out of the sky many years earlier.  Both peaks offer a lovely forest walk with lots of great views.  Hope you can join us ... wherever you are headed in the mountains, the weather looks great for this weekend!


NOTE:  Great weather is (finally!) predicted ... however, if weather reports change to unfavorable, I WILL RESCHEDULE. Also, all my hikes are dog friendly (and Mike will be coming!) -- if you don't like dogs, don't come.

 

The memorial stone at the crash site ...

 


MAPS, TRIP PLANS AND RESEARCH ESSENTIALS:


INFORMATION LINK (NEHH Elephant Mountain):   Peakbagger

INFORMATION LINK (NEHH Elephant Mountain):   FranklinSites.com

INFORMATION LINK (NEHH Elephant Mountain):   NewEnglandTrailConditions.com


INFORMATION LINK (Crash-Site Elephant Mountain):   Wikipedia

INFORMATION LINK (Crash-Site Elephant Mountain):   Durward J. Ferland, Jr.



WEATHER AND OTHER SUDDEN EVENTS CAN CAUSE SUDDEN CHANGES TO OR CANCELLATION OF THIS EVENT. YOU MUST CHECK BACK TO THE MEETUP.COM SITE OFTEN FOR UPDATES TO ANY OF MY HIKING EVENTS.

SEE YOU THERE! Julie and Mike 

 

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the following:  If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.  Full waiver can be found elsewhere on this site.  THANK YOU FOR UNDERSTANDING AND FOR HIKING SAFE!
item.how_to_find_us: Look for the Green Honda Element ...
item.name: MAINE (NEHH) SERIES: TWO ELEPHANTS (and Paying Respect to Fallen Servicemen)
